text:
o Jeremy Soule o

Love his work, from his well known work like Skyrim and Guild Wars to his earlier work on Total Annihilation and Secret of Evermore. It's all beautiful.
He's currently working on his very own symphony, titled "The Northerner". Release date is TBA, but I'm looking forward to it!

text: I played this game so much its such a beautiful world
author: WaxSkink

text: Summer of 2006; the colors TES's world painted mine.
author: Gustav Louw

text: This game is a masterpiece. I've invested way too much time in it, but it's seriously just that good. All the attention to detail makes it one of my favorite games of all time, and IMO one of the best games ever. Come to think of it, the same can be said for almost all of the TES games.
author: Lightwatch

text:
I personally think this may be the best game I have ever played and know of. The music and story was amazing, and sure the voice acting was rusty due to a severely low amount of voice actors, but the asthetics of this and all the rest of the game make it amazing. Skyrim was hard to enjoy even with dlc but with Oblivion I could enjoy the whole game on its own.
I play this on my day 1 Xbox360 and it still works with a midnight launch copy of oblivion. I just want to say if this was backwards compatible on Xbox 1, I would worship Todd Howard for that and I would not be able to sleep at all or simple be able to actually sleep. This game was perfectly made and it proves it, if only it were as praised as Skyrim.
author: AJBxxSlayer

text:
A lot of people don't like how simple Oblivion made questing, and hate 
Skyrim because it's so easy to get things done. Back in the Morrowind 
and Daggerfall days, you didn't get icons on your map telling you where 
to go and who to talk to. You actually had to chat up townsfolk, ask 
about people you were looking for, and half the time the person you were
 talking to would have no idea where they are. Even if they did know, it
 would usually be something vague, or directions to /another/ person who
 was better acquainted with whoever you really wanted to talk to. The 
worlds were more alive. Still a great soundtrack though.
author: ZhangJao

text: It might just be me, but the lack of voiceover in Morrowind was one of the things that made it kinda hard for me to play it. I would usually just skip through all the dialogues and re-read the journal if I missed something crucial. Other than that, the world seemed kinda dark to me (visually) all the time and I really craved mods but since I have a crappy PC, that's a no-go.
author: Senzorei

text: ZhangJao they would also give you wrong directions at times

text: This makes me think of a massive piece of stained-glass in an old cathedral in a major European city.

text: I have Oblivion and Skyrim for PS3.  I bought them without high hopes and they blew me away.  I got Oblivion first and it was amazing.  Skyrim impressed me with its controls and game play but Oblivion still seems like a larger world for some reason.  I felt that I have explored most of Skyrim after a short while but only touched Oblivion.
author: volbound1700

text: I am so glad this is on the list. This has been my favourite piece of VGM for as long as I can remember
author: Martyn Jones

text: I hated Oblivion but the soundtrack is very nice.
author: Will

text: +Dark Assassin9001 A lot of people don't like how simple Oblivion made questing, and hate Skyrim because it's so easy to get things done. Back in the Morrowind and Daggerfall days, you didn't get icons on your map telling you where to go and who to talk to. You actually had to chat up townsfolk, ask about people you were looking for, and half the time the person you were talking to would have no idea where they are. Even if they did know, it would usually be something vague, or directions to /another/ person who was better acquainted with whoever you really wanted to talk to. The worlds were more alive. I totally agree with Will.
author: ZhangJao

text: The biggest flaw in my mind was Oblivion's leveling system. Unless you power leveled every time, which I definitely didn't know to do until far too late in the game, the harder difficulties make enemies far more powerful than the player, which creates a very frustrating experience. Otherwise, I thoroughly enjoyed the hell out of the this game and it's world. The Dark Brotherhood storyline in probably one of my favorite storylines in gaming.
author: Patrick Kruse

text: I knew there was a reason why I hated Oblivion, and didn't give it much time. Thanks for reminding me! The levelling system was indeed atrocious, and in fact completely broken beyond repair. And I'm one of those awful people who judges a game vanilla, without looking to the modding community to fix it when the developers screw up.

text: @TheRitchardgaleHater True, but the oblivion world felt smaller because it was more monotonous. In morrowind you had a ridiculous amounts of different cultures, environments, and other variables. For example, the different houses in Morrowind built buildings differently, making it so that no city truly looked the same. Also, in Morrowind you can go from a swamp to a desert and everything in between incluing a forest of giant mushrooms in between. In oblivion you dont have that variety.

text: This game was great in every single way except it had one fundamental game breaking flaw.  The ability to go 100%camoflauge and basically become immortal against EVERY SINGLE THING IN THE GAME.  And you can get full camo 20% into the game.  It's kind of silly, enemies (and I mean every single enemy in the game) will just sit there and let you sit there indefinitely and beat them to death.  If they removed the ability to get 100% camoflage this game would be truly as good as it deserves to be.
